questions.question: List of headings
I) Harmony through competition
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is D (Origins). Paragraph A describes the beginning of the Olympics in Ancient Greece.
questions.correct_feedback: Excellent! Paragraph A discusses the origins of the Olympics, explaining how it "first began in Ancient Greece nearly 2700 years ago as a religious occasion" dedicated to Zeus.
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is D (Origins). Paragraph A focuses on how the Olympics started in Ancient Greece as a religious festival celebrating Zeus, making "Origins" the most suitable heading.

questions.question: I) Harmony through competition
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is I (Harmony through competition). Paragraph B focuses on the peaceful period during the Olympic Games.
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! Paragraph B emphasizes how the Olympics created peace during the festival, with wars suspended and conflicts halted, making "Harmony through competition" the perfect heading.
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is I (Harmony through competition). Paragraph B describes how "for the duration of the festival, there was peace" and "All wars – domestic and international – had to be suspended."

questions.question: I) Harmony through competition
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is B (Traditional discrimination). Paragraph C describes the exclusion of certain groups from the ancient Olympics.
questions.correct_feedback: Well done! Paragraph C discusses how "women and slaves, who were not allowed within the stadium," showing the traditional discrimination of the ancient Games.
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is B (Traditional discrimination). Paragraph C explains the exclusion of women and slaves from the Olympics, which was a form of traditional discrimination.

questions.question: I) Harmony through competition
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is G (Dissolution through conquest). Paragraph D describes how the Romans ended the ancient Olympic Games.
questions.correct_feedback: Excellent! Paragraph D explains how "the original Games were abolished after the Roman invasion in AD356," which is a dissolution through conquest.
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is G (Dissolution through conquest). Paragraph D states that "the original Games were abolished after the Roman invasion," ending the ancient Olympics.

questions.question: I) Harmony through competition
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is A (Re-emergence of the Games). Paragraph E discusses the revival of the Olympic Games in the modern era.
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! Paragraph E describes how "in 1896 that Baron Pierre de Coubertin...and Dimitrios Vikelas...revived the games," marking the re-emergence of the Olympics.
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is A (Re-emergence of the Games). Paragraph E explains how the Olympics were revived in 1896 after being abolished for over 1,500 years.

questions.question: I) Harmony through competition
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is E (The contemporary Olympiad). Paragraph F describes the modern Olympic Games as they exist today.
questions.correct_feedback: Well done! Paragraph F discusses the modern Olympics with "nearly 200 nationalities," the Winter Olympics, and Paralympics, perfectly described by "The contemporary Olympiad."
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is E (The contemporary Olympiad). Paragraph F focuses on today's Olympics, including its expansion to Winter Olympics and Paralympics.

questions.question: How many times has war cancelled the modern Olympics?
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "three". Check paragraph E which discusses war cancellations of the modern Olympics.
questions.correct_feedback: Excellent! Paragraph E states "World War I caused one game to be cancelled and World War II caused the cancellation of another two" – totaling three cancellations.
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is "three". Paragraph E explains that World War I cancelled one Olympics and World War II cancelled two, totaling three cancellations.

questions.question: Why were there no Olympics between 356 and 1896?
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "Roman invasion". Paragraph D provides this information.
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! Paragraph D clearly states "the original Games were abolished after the Roman invasion in AD356."
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is "Roman invasion". Paragraph D explains that the Games were abolished after the Roman invasion in AD356.

questions.question: To whom specifically were the original Olympics dedicated?
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "Zeus". Paragraph A mentions which god the original Olympics honored.
questions.correct_feedback: Well done! Paragraph A states "the festival was actually in praise of the god Zeus."
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is "Zeus". Paragraph A explains that the Olympics were "in praise of the god Zeus."

questions.question: Before AD356, how long was each Olympics?
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "five days". Paragraph D provides the duration of the ancient Olympics.
questions.correct_feedback: Excellent! Paragraph D mentions the Olympics "promoted, albeit for only five days, a period of peace."
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is "five days". Paragraph D states the Olympics lasted "for only five days."

questions.question: How many countries are represented in the modern Olympics?
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "nearly 200". Paragraph F discusses the number of nations in today's Olympics.
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! Paragraph F states "people of nearly 200 nationalities to come together."
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is "nearly 200". Paragraph F mentions "nearly 200 nationalities" participate in the modern Olympics.

questions.question: I) Problems overcome
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is E (Looking at alternatives). Paragraph B examines various energy alternatives.
questions.correct_feedback: Excellent! Paragraph B discusses various energy options like solar and wind, then introduces geothermal as "a viable alternative to fossil fuels," making "Looking at alternatives" the perfect heading.
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is E (Looking at alternatives). Paragraph B explores different renewable energy options before focusing on geothermal energy as an alternative.

questions.question: I) Problems overcome
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is A (The science of geothermal energy). Paragraph C explains the scientific mechanism of geothermal energy extraction.
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! Paragraph C explains the scientific process of geothermal energy, describing temperatures at different depths, pressure, steam turbines, and heat exchangers.
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is A (The science of geothermal energy). Paragraph C provides technical details about how geothermal energy works underground.

questions.question: I) Problems overcome
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is F (Global use). Paragraph D covers worldwide adoption of geothermal energy.
questions.correct_feedback: Well done! Paragraph D discusses geothermal use globally, mentioning multiple countries and including a table showing international generating capacity.
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is F (Global use). Paragraph D lists various countries using geothermal energy and provides comparative data in a table.

questions.question: I) Problems overcome
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is H (Unresolved drawbacks). Paragraph E lists several issues with geothermal energy.
questions.correct_feedback: Excellent! Paragraph E discusses problems like sites needing recovery time, corrosion, radioactive gases requiring "further research," and geological effects - all unresolved drawbacks.
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is H (Unresolved drawbacks). Paragraph E details various problems with geothermal energy that remain unsolved.

questions.question: Geothermal energy is the result of extracting heat from water passed through ______.
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "rocks". See paragraph B for information about how geothermal energy works.
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! Paragraph B states geothermal energy is "the heat contained in rocks beneath the earth's surface. Water is injected down a borehole and retrieved after being heated by the rocks."
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is "rocks". Paragraph B explains that water is "heated by the rocks" beneath the earth's surface.

questions.question: This energy may provide an alternative to ______.
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "fossil fuels". Paragraph B mentions what geothermal energy can replace.
questions.correct_feedback: Excellent! Paragraph B clearly states geothermal energy is "a viable alternative to fossil fuels."
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is "fossil fuels". Paragraph B describes geothermal as an alternative to fossil fuels.

questions.question: Not a new discovery, geothermal energy was first tapped by ______.
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "the Romans". Paragraph D provides historical information about early geothermal use.
questions.correct_feedback: Well done! Paragraph D states "People have been using hot spring water for a very long time – most famously, the Romans 2000 years ago at Bath in England."
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is "the Romans". Paragraph D mentions the Romans used hot spring water 2000 years ago.

questions.question: Only one quarter of a per cent of energy is extracted through this method in ______.
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "USA". The table in paragraph D shows this percentage.
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! The table in paragraph D shows USA with "0.25" in the "% of total" column, which is one quarter of a percent.
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is "USA". Check the table in paragraph D which shows 0.25% for USA.

questions.question: As well as blockages, water heated through aquifers is not used in boilers as it causes ______.
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "corrosion". Paragraph E discusses problems with using heated water in boilers.
questions.correct_feedback: Excellent! Paragraph E states "The water contains mineral salts which would eventually corrode or block the boiler systems."
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is "corrosion". Paragraph E explains that mineral salts in the water cause corrosion and blockages.

questions.question: Potential effects to the surrounding land also have to be taken into account by ______.
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "engineers". Paragraph E identifies who needs to consider land effects.
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! Paragraph E states "Engineers would also need to consider any possible effects on the local geology in unstable regions."
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is "engineers". Paragraph E mentions that engineers must consider geological effects.

questions.question: The cost is the main drawback for which form of power?
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "solar power". Paragraph B discusses the cost issue with this energy source.
questions.correct_feedback: Excellent! Paragraph B states "the cost of establishing efficient solar power sources remains prohibitive."
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is "solar power". Paragraph B mentions that solar power's cost is prohibitive.

questions.question: What is the advantage in boring deeper into the rock?
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "higher temperature". Paragraph C compares temperatures at different depths.
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! Paragraph C explains "at 3 km it may exceed 200 °C" compared to 100°C at 2km, showing higher temperature is the advantage of going deeper.
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is "higher temperature". Paragraph C shows that deeper depths produce higher temperatures.

questions.question: Why is New Zealand using geothermal energy more than any other country is?
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "volcanic environment". Paragraph D explains why New Zealand uses more geothermal energy.
questions.correct_feedback: Well done! Paragraph D states New Zealand leads "as a result of its naturally volcanic environment."
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is "volcanic environment". Paragraph D explains New Zealand's advantage is due to its volcanic nature.

questions.question: What potential emissions from boreholes need further investigation?
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "radioactive gases". Paragraph E discusses emissions requiring investigation.
questions.correct_feedback: Excellent! Paragraph E mentions "radioactive gases such as radon rising in boreholes. This latter issue requires further research."
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is "radioactive gases". Paragraph E states that radioactive gases need further research before they're considered safe.

questions.question: J) Effects of the natural environment
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is D (Artificial causes of acid rain). Paragraph B explains manmade sources of acid rain.
questions.correct_feedback: Excellent! Paragraph B discusses "the principal chemicals" causing acid rain and explains "the majority is unsurprisingly manmade," detailing artificial/manmade sources.
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is D (Artificial causes of acid rain). Paragraph B focuses on manmade sources like transportation, power plants, and industry.

questions.question: J) Effects of the natural environment
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is J (Effects of the natural environment). Paragraph C discusses natural filters and geological impacts.
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! Paragraph C discusses how "naturally occurring substances such as limestone" can neutralize acid rain, showing effects of the natural environment.
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is J (Effects of the natural environment). Paragraph C explains how natural geology either protects against or worsens acid rain effects.

questions.question: J) Effects of the natural environment
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is G (Secondary impact on flora and fauna). Paragraph D covers impacts on animals and crops.
questions.correct_feedback: Well done! Paragraph D discusses environmental impact on lakes, animals like otters, and farmland with reduced crop yields - all secondary impacts on flora and fauna.
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is G (Secondary impact on flora and fauna). Paragraph D describes effects on wildlife and plants beyond the direct acid rain damage.

questions.question: J) Effects of the natural environment
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is A (Impact on the urban landscape). Paragraph E discusses acid rain's effects on urban areas.
questions.correct_feedback: Excellent! Paragraph E focuses on cities, discussing monuments, structures, pipes, drinking water, visibility, and smog - all urban landscape impacts.
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is A (Impact on the urban landscape). Paragraph E describes how acid rain affects cities and urban infrastructure.

questions.question: J) Effects of the natural environment
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is B (Higher dispersal creates a global problem). Paragraph F discusses long-distance transport of acid rain.
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! Paragraph F explains how "tall chimneys dispersing pollutants high into the atmosphere" allow wind to blow acid rain "hundreds of miles" creating a global problem.
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is B (Higher dispersal creates a global problem). Paragraph F describes how acid rain now travels thousands of kilometers affecting distant regions.

questions.question: J) Effects of the natural environment
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is F (International reactions). Paragraph G describes international cooperation to address acid rain.
questions.correct_feedback: Well done! Paragraph G discusses "transboundary pollution" prompting "international responses" and "International legislation during the 1980s and 1990s."
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is F (International reactions). Paragraph G focuses on global legislative responses to acid rain pollution.

questions.question: A deterioration in lakes and forests in northern Europe was first noticed in ______.
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "the late 1970s". Check the opening of paragraph A.
questions.correct_feedback: Excellent! Paragraph A begins "In the late 1970s, people in northern Europe were observing a change in the lakes and forests."
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is "the late 1970s". Paragraph A states when the changes were first observed.

questions.question: Pollution in rain is a result of ______.
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "sulphuric and nitric acids". Paragraph A explains what causes acid rain.
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! Paragraph A states acid rain is "pollutants in rain, snow, hail and fog caused by sulphuric and nitric acids."
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is "sulphuric and nitric acids". Paragraph A identifies these as the cause of pollution in rain.

questions.question: Nearly half of manmade sources of acid rain are due to ______.
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "transportation sources". Paragraph B breaks down sources of manmade acid rain.
questions.correct_feedback: Well done! Paragraph B states "transportation sources account for 40%" - nearly half of the manmade sources listed.
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is "transportation sources". Paragraph B shows transportation accounts for 40% of manmade acid rain.

questions.question: Some animals have declined in number by over 50% because of scarcer ______.
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "fish". Paragraph D discusses the food chain impact of acid rain.
questions.correct_feedback: Excellent! Paragraph D explains "animals that rely on fish as a food source" and mentions "American otter have had their numbers reduced by over half."
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is "fish". Paragraph D connects declining fish populations to animal population decreases.

questions.question: Land used for farming is becoming ______.
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "less productive". Paragraph D discusses agricultural impacts.
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! Paragraph D states acid rain is "destroying the effectiveness of farmland, making it significantly less productive."
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is "less productive". Paragraph D describes how acid rain reduces farmland productivity.

questions.question: Urban household water supplies are contaminated by ______.
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "toxic metals". Paragraph E discusses contamination of water supplies.
questions.correct_feedback: Well done! Paragraph E states "the drinking water is laced with toxic metals freed from metal pipes by the acidity."
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is "toxic metals". Paragraph E explains how acidity releases toxic metals from pipes into drinking water.

questions.question: Air pollution is travelling further as it is disgorged through ______.
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "tall chimneys". Paragraph F discusses how pollution dispersal has changed.
questions.correct_feedback: Excellent! Paragraph F states pollution "can be transported thousands of kilometres due to the introduction of tall chimneys dispersing pollutants high into the atmosphere."
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is "tall chimneys". Paragraph F explains that tall chimneys allow pollution to travel much farther.

questions.question: Legislation passed in the 1980s and the 1990s was a response to ______.
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "transboundary pollution". Paragraph G explains what prompted international legislation.
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! Paragraph G states "Transboundary pollution, the spread of acid rain across political and international borders, has prompted a number of international responses. International legislation during the 1980s and 1990s..."
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is "transboundary pollution". Paragraph G links international legislation to the cross-border nature of acid rain.

questions.question: A solution to the problem must involve a ______.
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is "cooperative global effort". Paragraph G's conclusion states what is needed to solve the problem.
questions.correct_feedback: Excellent! Paragraph G concludes "without a cooperative global effort, the problem of acid rain will not simply blow away," indicating this is necessary for a solution.
questions.incorrect_feedback: The correct answer is "cooperative global effort". Paragraph G emphasizes that global cooperation is essential to solve acid rain.

reading_texts.title: Reading Passage 1 - A brief history of the Olympics
reading_texts.content:
A. Most people have heard of the Olympics, a sporting event held every four years, where people from around the world congregate in one place to compete in various sporting events. But how much is known of its history? The Olympics first began in Ancient Greece nearly 2700 years ago as a religious occasion, very different from the secular event we see now. It was primarily a festival celebrating the ancient Greek gods. Named after the goddess Olympia, the festival was actually in praise of the god Zeus and was held in a specially constructed stadium called The Hippodrome. Unlike the modern Olympics, there were very few events, the most popular being running, fighting and javelin throwing.

B. For the athletes, the honour of winning was the reason for participation, not only for themselves, but also for their city, as the winner of each competition was given prizes to bestow on the citizens of his hometown. Prizes were often food – grain and meat – but occasionally also precious metals. Naturally, this engendered a degree of rivalry amongst competitors and cities, but one of the most notable aspects of the Olympics was that, for the duration of the festival, there was peace, at least outside the arena. By government decree, there were no arguments or hostilities, convicted criminals were to be treated well and the death penalty was not carried out. All wars – domestic and international – had to be suspended. Nothing of importance was discussed as the games became the paramount focus of the nation.

C. Despite the prizes, the honours and the enforcement of peace, the Games were not entirely philanthropic in nature. In accordance with the customs of the time, they still carried the traditional exclusion of women and slaves, who were not allowed within the stadium. Transgression of this rule resulted in severe punishment. It was not until 1900 that women were finally allowed to compete.

D. Nonetheless, for nearly 700 years, the Olympics represented something noble in that it promoted, albeit for only five days, a period of peace around which the whole country could gather. It was somewhat ironic, then, that the original Games were abolished after the Roman invasion in AD356, and for a period of just over a millennium and a half, there were no more Olympics.

E. It was in 1896 that Baron Pierre de Coubertin, a Frenchman, and Dimitrios Vikelas, a Greek, revived the games. Fittingly, the first of the modern Olympics was held in Greece, but although the intentions of the Games were good, they no longer represented the original ideals of the Olympics. World War I caused one game to be cancelled and World War II caused the cancellation of another two – a far cry from the period of peace the games first inspired. To try and revive the spirit of peace and understanding that the original games represented, Baron de Coubertin designed an Olympic flag with five intertwining rings which symbolised the union of the five continents. This was first used at the Antwerp Olympics in 1920 together with the release of doves at the beginning of the Games as a symbol of peace. However, athletes competing to be the best in the world, financial rewards in the form of sponsorship, financial problems and allegations of drug abuse have further tarnished what was once the embodiment of a desire to bring people together harmoniously.

F. However, there is still much to admire in the Olympics of today. It has become an opportunity for people of nearly 200 nationalities to come together in the spirit of friendly competition, much as they did nearly 3000 years ago. Now the rewards come in the form of medals and the knowledge that the athlete is one of the best in the world. The importance of the games has been reinforced with the introduction of the Winter Olympics and the Paralympics Games, the latter of which is specifically for people with physical disabilities. It can now be said that the Olympic Games is truly a competition for all people.

reading_texts.title: Reading Passage 2 - Tapping the depths
reading_texts.content:
A: It has been predicted that, at the current rate, New Zealand will increase its energy demand by 20% in the next 10 years. It has also been predicted that emissions from fossil fuels could rise by as much as 45%, a statistic that has prompted the government to announce plans to increase renewable energy supplies by nearly 50% as part of a NZ$79 million energy strategy.

B: Of the available options, the cost of establishing efficient solar power sources remains prohibitive and there is opposition to the location of wind farms near populated areas. Most of New Zealand's renewable energy currently comes from hydro schemes, but this solution alone is not sufficient. Indeed, the Energy Minister of New Zealand stated that the country has been slow to utilise its sustainable forms of energy production. However, there is one renewable source of energy that is currently proving itself a viable alternative to fossil fuels: geothermal energy, the heat contained in rocks beneath the earth's surface. Water is injected down a borehole and retrieved after being heated by the rocks.

C: In aquifers (porous rocks like limestone and sandstone about 2 km beneath the earth's surface), the water temperature may reach 100 °C, and at 3 km it may exceed 200 °C. The high pressure underground prevents the water from turning to steam, but at the surface it can be allowed to expand and drive a steam turbine linked to an electricity generator. The water is then pumped from the borehole to a heat exchanger from which it can be used for a number of purposes.

D: People have been using hot spring water for a very long time – most famously, the Romans 2000 years ago at Bath in England. If sufficiently hot, spring water can be used to provide heating for buildings. It is also possible to use geothermal energy to generate electricity. Of all countries experimenting with its exploitation, New Zealand is leading the field, with geothermal energy accounting for nearly 30% of its total needs as a result of its naturally volcanic environment. No other country has reached 1% as yet, although in the UK it is estimated that geothermal power could supply 10% of electricity for 125 years if it could be exploited efficiently. The world's largest geothermal power station is at Geyserville, California, which generates 1500 MW. Other nations generating electricity this way include China, Indonesia, Japan, Kenya, Mexico, New Zealand, the Philippines and Russia.

Generating capacity (GW) | % of total
New Zealand | 2.21 | 29.4
USA | 1.74 | 0.25
Pacific region | 0.50 | 0.22
Japan | 0.24 | 0.13
Turkey | 0.02 | 0.11

E: Although it fulfils most of the requirements demanded of an alternative energy source, geothermal energy is not a perfect solution. Extracting the heat in large quantities at a particular site lowers the temperature, meaning the site must then be abandoned at least until it recovers, which could take many years. The water contains mineral salts which would eventually corrode or block the boiler systems that extract the energy from the water. In addition, although using geothermal energy does not release carbon dioxide or pollutants, there is the problem of the sulphurous smell of hot aquifers and possibility of radioactive gases such as radon rising in boreholes. This latter issue requires further research before it is considered safe. Engineers would also need to consider any possible effects on the local geology in unstable regions, such as subsidence or slippage.

reading_texts.title: Reading Passage 3 - Poison rain
reading_texts.content:
A: In the late 1970s, people in northern Europe were observing a change in the lakes and forests around them. Areas once famous for the quality and quantity of their fish began to decline, and areas of once-green forest were dying. The phenomenon they witnessed was acid rain – pollutants in rain, snow, hail and fog caused by sulphuric and nitric acids.

B: The principal chemicals that cause these acids are sulphur dioxide and oxides of nitrogen, both by-products of burning fossil fuels (coal, oil and gas). A percentage of acid rain is natural, from volcanoes, forest fires and biological decay, but the majority is unsurprisingly manmade. Of this, transportation sources account for 40%; power plants 30%; industrial sources 25%; and commercial institutions and residues 5%. What makes these figures particularly disturbing is that since the 1970s, nitrogen oxide emissions have tripled. Each year the global atmosphere is polluted with 20 billion tons of carbon dioxide, 130 million tons of sulphur dioxide, more than three million tons of toxic metals, and a wealth of synthetic organic compounds, many of which are proven causes of cancer, genetic mutations and birth defects.

C: For natural causes of acid rain, nature has provided a filter. Naturally occurring substances such as limestone or other antacids can neutralise this acid rain before it enters the water cycle, thereby protecting it. However, areas with a predominantly quartzite- or granite-based geology and little top soil have no such effect, and the basic environment shifts from an alkaline to an acidic one. Recycled and intensified through the water table, acid rain has reached such a degree in some parts of the world that rainfall is now 40 times more acidic than normal – the same acidic classification as vinegar.

D: Environmentally, the impact is devastating. Lakes and the life they support are dying, unable to withstand such a battering. This has a direct effect on the animals that rely on fish as a food source. Certain species of American otter have had their numbers reduced by over half in the last 20 years, for example. Yet this is not the only effect. Nitrogen oxides, the principal reagent in acid rain, react with other pollutants to produce ozone, a major air pollutant responsible for destroying the effectiveness of farmland, making it significantly less productive. With scientists working on producing ever bigger and longer lasting genetically modified foods, some farmers are reporting abnormally low yields. Tomatoes grow to only half their full weight and the leaves, stalks and roots of other crops never reach full maturity.

E: Naturally it rains on cities too, eating away stone monuments and concrete structures, and corroding the pipes which channel the water away to the lakes where the cycle is repeated. Paint exposed to rain is not lasting as long due to the pollution in the atmosphere speeding up the corrosion process. In some communities the drinking water is laced with toxic metals freed from metal pipes by the acidity. After any period of non-use, we are encouraged to run taps for at least 60 seconds to flush any excess debris, as increased concentrations of metals in plumbing such as lead, copper and zinc result in adverse health effects. As if urban skies were not already grey enough, typical visibility has declined from ten to four miles, in many American cities, as acid rain turns into smog. Also, now there are indicators that the components of acid rain are a health risk, linked to human respiratory disease.

F: Acid rain itself is not an entirely new phenomenon. In the nineteenth century, acid rain fell both in towns and cities. What is new, and of great concern, is that it can be transported thousands of kilometres due to the introduction of tall chimneys dispersing pollutants high into the atmosphere, allowing strong wind currents to blow the acid rain hundreds of miles from its source. Thus the areas where acid rain falls are not necessarily the areas where the pollution comes from. Pollution from industrial areas of England are damaging forests in Scotland and Scandinavia. Acids from the Midwest United States are blown into northwest Canada. More and more regions are beginning to be affected, and given that 13 of the world's most polluted cities are in neighbouring Asia, countries like Australia and New Zealand are increasingly under threat.

G: Transboundary pollution, the spread of acid rain across political and international borders, has prompted a number of international responses. International legislation during the 1980s and 1990s has led to reductions in sulphur dioxide emissions in many countries but reductions in emissions of nitrogen oxides have been much less, leading to the conclusion that without a cooperative global effort, the problem of acid rain will not simply blow away.
